Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Toward a Predictive Theory of Star Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Krumholz will study of one of the most important and least understood processes in the cosmos, the formation of stars. As noted in the project summary of this proposal "stars are the engines of the Universe", the energy produced by the nuclear reactions in the interior of stars is the only significant non-gravitational source of energy in the cosmos. This energy helps govern the evolution of galaxies, the creation of the heavy elements in the universe and the formation of planets. This project will attempt to broaden our understanding of star formation by addressing the following three questions:
-- What determines the stellar mass function, and does it vary with environment?
-- What determines how stars cluster, and how is the efficiency of star formation effected in these environments?
-- What sets the star formation rate, and does it vary with environment and/or over cosmic time?
The ultimate goal of the research is a fully predictive theory of star formation.

The Broader Impacts of the proposal are centered on the work that the PI will perform by teaching prisoners math and science courses. The PI will offer these classes to inmates at a local detention facility. While the classes offered are not directly connected to the research in this proposal, these classes will produce a connection between the scientific community and this severely under served and mostly minority community. The inmates have the chance to earn college credit for successfully completing one of the classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has led to a significantly improved understanding of the process by which stars form. The major accomplishments supported by the award can be broken into three rough categories:

1) The star formation rate at galactic scales. In this area, work supported by this award led to a greatly improved understanding of how and why the star formation rate in a galaxy correlates with the chemical state of its interstellar medium, and to the discovery of a fundamental commonality between star formation in many different types of galaxies and across a wide range of spatial scales.

2) Stellar clustering. The work supported by this award has helped lead to a new understanding of why how star formation is clustered, but why most clusters dissolve shortly after formation. This work in particular clarified the role of radiation pressure and stellar winds as feedback mechanisms in the most massive star clusters.

3) The stellar mass distribution (also known as the initial mass function). Work in this area demonstrated that the mass scale for stars is linked with nuclear processes occurring in stellar centers, which then affects star formation via radiation feedback from accreting stars on their surrounding envelopes. This resolves the question of why the typical mass of stars lies close to the mass scale required for initiation of nuclear burning.
